newsitem.title: USA: U.S. targets four countries for copyright cases.
newsitem.headline: U.S. targets four countries for copyright cases.

text.p: U.S. Trade Representative Charlene Barshefsky said Wednesday the United States will initiate World Trade Organization cases against Denmark, Sweden, Ireland and Ecuador for failing to take adequate action to protect copyrights and other intellectual property.

Barshefsky said the United States may also initiate WTO cases against Greece and Luxembourg in the near future if they fail to meet their obligations under an international agreement that protects copyrights and other intellectual property.

The WTO actions were announced as part of the U.S. Trade Representative's so-called Special 301 annual review of how countries protect intellectual property, which is a major source of revenue for U.S. companies and the economy.

"The Special 301 annual review is one of the most effective instruments in our trade policy arsenal," Barshefsky said in a statement. "It is much more than an in-depth review. It provides a direct route to press countries to approve their IPR (intellectual property rights) practices."

The USTR said Denmark and Sweden had not implemented their obligations under the WTO Agreement on Trade-Related Aspects of Intellectual Property Rights (TRIPS) to provide relief in civil enforcement proceedings.

The United States said Ireland has not amended its copyright law to comply with TRIPS obligations. It said Ecuador has failed to meet its obligations in a number of areas on patents, copyrights and trademarks.
